bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Gustaf E. Lambert, July 27, 1940

div1.p: Andrus shares family news. He inquires about Lambert's health and circumstances.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Gustaf E. Lambert, July 27, 1940
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
7-27-40
FROM GUST LAMBERT
Dear Friend Lambert:
div1.p:
You have been in my mind much of the time lately. I've
wondered how you are managing and whether you would be able to
to retain your job.

I realize, of course, that you have suffered a terrible loss
and one that will affect your future - to say nothing of
what it will do to your feelings. I know that this is
not the first hard jolt that has been handed you and that
you are too good a soldier to allow this to get you.

Then, too, I have wondered whether you have heard anything
about your bill in congress. If the time they have taken
on the selective service legislation is any criterion, is is
not likely that your bill will get action for a long time.

We have had a little excitement in the neighborhood since you
were here. The factory buildings of the Hollingshead Co.,
in the square above us, together with 67 residences - some in
the same block and some across the street - were burned on the
afternoon of July 30. It was the largest fire Camden has
ever had. Ten lives were lost and the damage will amount
to a million and a half. If there had not been a strong
wind blowing the fire away from us we would probably have been
burned out.

Saw a squib in the paper a few days ago to the effect that
“Capt. Thomas M. England, one of the heroes who risked their
lives 30 years ago in Cuba experimenting with yellow fever con-
trol will retire from active service Oct. 31, upon reaching
the statutory age limit of 64 years.” The lad has had it
pretty soft all these years, hasn't he?

Had a very brief note from Schwieger, yesterday, saying that
he is in the country and will write me when he returns.

The state conventions of the Veterans of Foriegn Wars and the
American Lagion were both held in Camden, this year. The
parades of both passed our house and I had a good chance to
look 'em over. Things like that help to break the monotony.

Mrs. Andrus joins me in sending kindest regards and every good
wish. I know it is not easy for you to write but I will
appreciate hearing how you are getting along, if it is only a
few lines.
